If I had to give my two cents worth on why quantum mechanics is so hard to accept, I guess it comes down to the question "Does a single reality exist? In the face of the double slit experiment (superposition) and Bell's Inequality (no hidden variable), a simple "yes" answer is hard to defend.

It seems that the only other possible metaphysical positions are:

1. A qualified yes, because reality in itself is fundamentally unknowable. We may be able to mathematically model it, but we cannot understand it.
2. Maybe or maybe not, but the question is irrelevant. Having a single reality as a first principle is unnecessary for physics to proceed.
3. No, because there is no reality. Reality is an illusion
4. No, because there are multiple realities. Realities are reproducing like bunny rabbits.

As untenable as having a single reality is, none of these other options are any more appealing. Why can't we have our cake and eat it to?

I am a bit of an optimist, so I think we will eventually be able to make sense of QM (and relativity and the standard model). In order for that to happen, I think the following will have to take place. We will have to:

1. Refine our concept of reality and our role in it.
2. Recognize the little bit of truth in each of the metaphysical positions above.
3. Combine those "truths" into a single model.

The model will probably be so simple and out-of-the-box that reactions to it will range from a V-8 moment to vehement distaste. It will be like a truly great movie, which can simultaneously alter lives and get critics to pillory the screenwriter and director.

Some kid somewhere in the world is probably thinking right now "What if …" because they don't know better. It just takes one.

IMHO, the 'observation' that collapses the wave function is NOT the person opening the box to see whether the cat is dead or alive. The 'observation' is the geiger counter either observing or not observing a radioactive decay. I.e., the quantum mechanical 'observer' does not have to be conscious. It can be an instrument, or a piece of film, etc.

Let's be kind to the cat and not actually perform this experiment as stated. Instead, let's substitute an electronic clock for the cat, and set up the experiment so that if the geiger counter detects a particle decay at the right time, it will trigger the clock to begin counting time. Otherwise, the clock will remain stuck at zero. Then we open the box a week later, and see what happened. I predict that the clock will be either still stuck at zero, because it was never triggered. Or it will show the full time elapsed since it was triggered at the beginning of the experiment.

There's going to be a wrinkle in that cloth. Could it be that the wrinkle of this cloth, or field, is what we see as an 'electron?' So the probability of that wrinkle appearing is expressed as a wave function? Maybe the act of observation affects that field, smoothing the wrinkles in a way that forces them to manifest as single "particles." Kinda like how if you put your finger on one part of the cloth, the wrinkles will form in a different pattern when the cloth is moved (by adding or subtracting matter/energy).

Does this analogy work, or am I just coming up with an excessive way of explaining the same phenomenon that superposition describes? Or is this just string theory, but explained wrong? Because to me it feels like this analogy can help explain why 'quantum tunneling' and spooky action at a distance seems to occur. If you look at all particles as wrinkles that manifest in the cloth, then it kinda explains why there's spillover from time to time and quantum particles just seem to "poof" in and out of existence. But we don't really have a means of measuring the field itself, do we? It feels like we're just looking at the wrinkles all the time and not the cloth.

Respectfully, the title doesn't really reflect the video, which lost its way and went into the whole nature of reality, which needs LOTS of videos to cover properly.
Narrowing it down specifically to the thought experiment, it is correct that Schrodinger was rubbishing the concept of superposition in particular and the Copenhagen Interpretation in general as preposterous. Whilst the thought experiment itself is amusing and fascinating, it is a flawed argument that does NOT demonstrate that superposition doesn't exist.
The cat is not in superposition - THE PARTICLE DETERMINING ITS FATE IS. The cat cannot be in superposition because this state only happens to individual fundamental particles. In the cat, billions of particles have combined to make a complex organism. The consequence of these particles all interacting with each other is the mutual collapse of their wave functions, meaning they lose superposition and are fixed in a localised position.
The cat is not both alive and dead, it's alive OR dead, depending on whether the radioactive particle has decayed or not, because superposition is irrelevant to particles in large groups such as a cat.
The nature of reality and the Copenhagen Interpretation of Quantum Mechanics is of course fascinating, but you can't cover it in just a few paragraphs!

Sorry, but the explanations given in the video are misleading and sometimes completely wrong. Superposition does not mean "both dead and alive"! Later in the video, the author says "that was Schroedinger's point!", but it is obvious that she has not even bothered to read Schroedinger's original paper and just replicates the most common misunderstandings about the problem. The point made by Schrödinger was not about "simultaneously" living and dead cat, but about an interplay (incoherence) between descriptions of macroscopic and microscopic phenomena in Quantum Mechanics. Unfortunately, most popular presentations of the paradox are like that, and even professional scientists (who never spent any time seriously learning about the problem) tend to believe they are correct. It is so frustrating to see fellow physicists just go to YouTube and publicly spread bad science based on sloppy education and hasty research. I am shocked to see such an award-winning, popular science communicator join this group. Judging from comments, thousands of misguided people walked away from the computer screen, even more confused than before watching the video, but actually believing they have learned something true. YouTubers should feel some moral obligation to seriously prepare their content because of their influence and the way they shape understanding of science. 

If you want to understand what the paradox was about, I recommend you to read the paper by Schrödinger, which has been translated into English (for non-German readers). If you prefer a popular explanation, the book by Jim Baggot "Quantum Reality" contains a very accessible (but serious) description of interpretations of QM. The "state of physics today" (citing the poll of 150 physicists, "interpretation does not matter, the math works", "physicists have no idea", etc.) provided in the video just reveals that the author does not know what she is talking about. She falsely attributes her lack of understanding to the whole community of physicists, which I find deeply appalling. 

Finally, an electron is not a "physical particle"? What does "physical" mean then? No, Copenhagen Interpretation says that the "position" is a classical term that does not accurately describe the micro-world. Why would it, since we (humans) developed our notion of position based on experience with objects of visible lengths, while the subatomic reality was for thousands of years outside of the realm of our language?

I haven't yet been convinced of the double-slit experiment interpretation that a particle interacts with itself as it passes through the double-slits to the collector.  I state this based on where the first particle always lands on the collector each time, this experiment is repeated.  In my mind, each particle interacts with the path of the previous n particles.  It's almost like some residual quantum "scent" or field remains after each particle zips by and the next one through the slit reacts to it, as does the next one to the previous one(s), and so on and so forth.  Let me put it this way.  If we had 1,000 different scientists around the globe each perform the double-slit experiment with only one single particle each, and then each scientist reported the location of where their particle landed, would we see the wave pattern in aggregate?  The answer, I believe, is no.  If a particle were indeed interacting with itself, we would expect to see a wave pattern in aggregate.  Thoughts?

Historically, Schrödiger’s Cat was his reaction to a long discussion with Einstein about the EPR paper. The EPR paper argued that the Copenhagen interpretation couldn’t be the final theory of QM because it was inconsistent with some “obviously true assumptions. Schrödinger was trying to show what bothered Einstein, by showing the weird abstract description of particles wouldn’t make sense to us if we were talking about macroscopic objects.

(Bell eventually showed that the “obviously true” assumptions can’t all be true. Sorry!)

In this then, there would be no observer opening the box but rather a chain of interdependent events which would at their end, in effect, be reaching out to the observer after the fact. In other words, the acid leaking from the box would only be possible were the cat dead and only dead. No dead cat, no leaking acid to alarm the observer that he might turn to observe. To illuminate further….that necessary for the Schroedinger version of this scheme is that there be no consequence of events of the cat’s state as either alive or dead or even potentially one or the other. The cat’s state as alive or dead is the end of the sequence of events contained within the box. In my version in which the cat’s state is nested within a line of other deterministic events, those subsequent to the cat’s state cannot be realized materially unless the cat were dead and only dead. The observer would not have looked at all but for the process having in a sense “reached out” to alert him to its presence. If as might be claimed that his observation would cause the wave form to collapse and the condition of the acid dripping to manifest then how could it have been manifest already that it might capture his attention that he might turn to observe it then to cause the wave form to collapse so that it could be dripping which it was in the first place? This makes no sense and defies the same brand or current of logic by which the experiment was initially defined. I would venture that if this cannot be resolved by the proponents of superposition, one then has to question the ability of composite entities to be in superposition, ever. So, we see that here is no wave form here and thus no superposition of the cat. A great deal of physics would fall away in the exposition of such an error with this superposition theory, not merely inviting alternative ontological possibilities but rather demanding their consideration. Silly notions of multi-verses, cyclical universe existing back infinitely and human perception as a component of the means of material existence would all be dispensed with.

The "many worlds" interpretation results fundamentally from the fact that quantum physicists are not biologists. A particle can have superposition and can experience as many universes as it wants. You can't. Why? Because you are not an object. You are a process. You are a walking, talking ecosystem, at least half nonhuman by cell count, and continually swapping particles with the world around you. So "you" could exist momentarily in two or more universes simultaneously, but the various versions of you would immediately start dissolving into their respective environments and lose their physical identity.

Actually, this problem of identity was anticipated by the classical Greeks in the Ship of Theseus Paradox. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ship_of_Theseus

Here's a presentation at the Royal Institution which addresses the issue. The presenter argues that quantum mechanics makes sense in its own frame of reference and that our problems with it result from our persistent efforts to shove it into our macro-world frame of reference:

I mean... It's not THAT hard to understand. A particle is basically a quantity of mass/energy occupying a kind of bell curve of space (superposition) with the average location of the mass/energy being what we think of as its conventional position. When it interacts with something it's forced to occupy a specific part on that bell curve collapsing it (with the spot being more probable in the center of said curve etc, and the size of the spot being defined by the restrictive nature of the interaction). As it continues to move the curve gradually expands again.
With the twin slit experiment what you're basically doing is only partially collapsing the occupied bell curve when it's just the two slits (it's passing through a restricted but less specified area). If you have it interact with something in such a controlled manner that you mostly collapse the curve (ie: measuring the location), the curve doesn't have enough time to expand enough to pass through both slits.

The astonishing implication of the Copenhagen interpretation is that choosing to never look in the box preserves the superposition. At a larger scale, you could say that ignorance (being unaware of the contents of the box) maximizes the possibilities of the universe (i'm pretty sure that's backwards to how reality actually works). The chance for the particle to decay has nothing to do with whether you observe it or not. It is self-determining (according to a type of ordering we humans perceive as 'random' or unpredictable; just because we don't understand something well enough to predict it, doesn't mean it is 'disordered' or 'random', only that the complexity of the ordering mechanism exceeds the 'resolution' of our comprehension or awareness), not determined by your measurement. If the Copenhagen interpretation were true, you could PREVENT decay by depriving the particle in question of the resolving external measurement. If nothing measures it, it can't decay. I think that's self-evidently in direct contradiction to what can be readily observed: the universe does what it does, whether or not we are aware of it, and whether or not we look at it. Choosing to ignore something will not prevent it from proceeding along its natural progression. Pretending something does not exist, will not preserve the possibility that it doesn't. Either it is, or it isn't. The Schrodinger's Cat superposition would actually be an illusion (a "quantum phantasm," if you will...) because either the particle has decayed, or it hasn't; you just don't know what's in the box because you haven't looked, and so you assume answering "both at once" is a suitable answer, but it's incorrect, because only one possibility can be true. There are two acceptable answers to the question "is Schrodinger's Cat dead or alive?" One is "yes" (because it is EITHER dead OR alive); the other is "we don't know because we can't predict it and haven't looked." Just because you don't know, or can't know, which of two possibilities is true, does not mean both can be true at once.

However, cats are not exactly 'quantum' objects, so despite the valid point being made with the thought experiment, it's a bit dubious from inception.

The point is: just because you do not yet know why something you imagine is impossible, does not mean that it remains possible until you discover why it can't be. It's impossible now, you just haven't learned why yet. Refusing to learn that something is impossible, does not prevent it from being impossible; especially if it already is.

Reason why quantum mechanics exists is because once we measure something at quantum level, we destroy that experiment by measuring it. Shrödinger's cat is about that - once you open the box, you will only find out if the cat is dead or alive, but not how long exactly it takes to kill a cat with that kind of setup. By doing that experiment over and over, you will get statistics of how long it takes to kill a cat with certain probability. And that is the wave functions. Because the curve of that function looks like a wave. So unlike in experiments in normal sizes, where you can hook a cat up to a EKG and determine exactly when the cat is dead, at quantum level, the only thing that you have is a wave function - in 1 min. a cat will die with probability of 13%, in 2 min. with probability of 21%, in 3 min. with probability of 56%,...etc.
In conclusion, quantum mechanics replaces the luxury of precise measurements with math.

As an "armchair scientist", i.e. an informed lay person, my natural tendency is to feel most comfortable with Many Worlds Interpretation, because of its simplicity. To me it feels much tidier to postulate huge numbers of worlds representing factors of the wave equation, with copies of me in each... I know most people find that crazy, but there's a certain elegance to it because it takes the conscious mind out of the equation once you insist that it's part of the universe. It even seems, on the surface at least, to explain entanglement without any spookiness (the particles aren't communicating instantaneously, they're already in a particular configuration in the universe you happen to be in but you don't know which that is until you look).

I sense that there's something I'm missing in all this, something that makes me accept MWI readily when many physicists don't. I wish I understood completely where that difference arises, but perhaps it's not possible to simplify the maths enough for people like me to grok it fully. So my take on the double slit experiment is that the particles are not real, they are discrete quanta of energy caused by excitations in the EM quantum field.

The problem with the wave/particle thing as an analogy for what's happening at a quantum level (which we cannot directly observe) is we are only thinking about the particle moving from one place to another, and not the entire experiment as a system that is interacting with itself, and so we place a huge burden on the particle/wave to explain everything we observe.

When it is "detected" it at the far side, there is a discrete quanta of energy discharged, but the same discrete quanta is also absorbed, and in doing so, the detector is changed. But why one location, and not a smear? Well, electrons simply don't behave like that (Pauli exclusion principle). There has to be room in an available electron shell for one electron worth of energy.

The detector measures a discrete quanta of energy by reacting with and absorbing a particle worth of energy,, which falls to a lower energy state, which we know from the photoelectric effect, happens at discrete quanta.

The quantum states of the receiving end, the randomized locations and temporary changes in distribution of electrons (like via London dispersion forces) around the atoms on the detector, determine who has room to absorb an electron's worth of energy.

So it isn't that spooky or weird right? At least, that's the understanding that I have come to on my own.

But doesn't this thought experiment rest upon a misunderstanding of what "measuring" means. It is the PHYSICAL act of measuring (e.g. the detector in the double slit experiment) that causes the wave function to collapse (according to the Copenhagen Interpretation). It has nothing to do with a conscious observer. To measure something (on the quantum level) requires interacting with it in some way, and it is this physical interaction that makes the whatever it is you're measuring become determinate rather than probabilistic. In order for the decay of the radioactive material to trigger the hammer, it has to be measured. So the wave function collapses then, BEFORE the hammer smashes the vial of acid. Therefore, the cat is never in a state of superposition. (And neither is the hammer--why does no one ever mention the hammer?)

Also, if a conscious observer WERE required to make the wave function collapse (which it isn't), then the CAT is a conscious observer. That's always bugged me more than anything else about this thought experiment; the way scientists implicitly think of their experimental subjects as objects.

The idea that a superposition doesn't mean its one or the other and we just don't know which - that its something else - isn't quite correct. The thing is, in QM one is dealing with state descriptions that are only capable of providing probabilities of where a particle is, because more precise information is inherently unknowable. And a physical scenario A where we can at most predict that the particle is 50% likely to be at position x1 and 50% likely to be at x2 is a different physical scenario to B the one where we can predict that it is 100% likely to be at x1 and 0% likely to be at x2, which is in turn different to C where its 100% likely to be at x2 and 0% likely to be at x1. Scenario A is a superposition of B and C, and this does not mean that the scenario is either B or C and we don't know which, A,B and C are three different physical scenarios. But, this also doesn't mean that in the 50% split scenario A that the particle is in some sort of limbo, we are still dealing with standard knowledge based probability, but it is a case of different physical scenarios corresponding to different probabilistic predictions. Even though A is a different physical scenario to either of B or C, it is still the case that the particle is either at position x1 or x2 but we don't know which and can't know unless a measurement takes place which changes the whole physical scenario. Trying to interpret the superposition as the particle being in limbo is one of the things that produces irrational nonsense. With the cat there is the additional complication that it is a multi-particle system which is not correctly modeled as simply two situations alive vs dead. "Here we are nearly 100 years later", still talking confused nonsense about [the interpretation of] QM. And it really is an appaling situation. Foundations-illiterate physicists (i.e. almost all of them!), steeped in the antiquated mathematical physics and quantum foundations of their textbooks, and their folklore, typically can't even get right what Schrödinger was doing in his 1935 "Cat paper": there was no Copenhagen Interpretation for him to criticise then! What he was actually doing - quite correctly - was warning against a naive, "psiontological", interpretation: "It is typical of these cases that an indeterminacy originally restricted to the atomic domain becomes transformed into macroscopic indeterminacy, which can then be resolved by direct observation. That prevents us from so naively accepting as valid a “blurred model” for representing reality." But of course far more damaging than such historical errors is this persistence of the idea that QM is very weird and difficult to interpret, and the serious conceptual errors - "werewaves", "particles in two places at once", various entanglement related nonsense - that accompany it. Take the "werewave" issue for example. The ("ordinary" as opposed to field theoretic) quantum model of a particle is unambiguously a model of a particle - not a wave nor even something that sometimes behaves as a wave. From a modern math. phys. and QF informed perspective, the closest interpretation to "the" Copenhagen Interpretation is the recognition that QM is essentially just (operational, algebraic) probabilistic mechanics. Regrettably, and rather scandalously in my opinion, the broader physics community has spectacularly failed to keep up with the advances in math. phys. and foundations that have facilitated that understanding.

My personal interpretation of the Schrodinger's cat experiment is thus:

The many many uncountably many particles that comprise the cat are all constantly interacting with each other, and therefore, measuring each other and collapsing each other's quantum states into a total system state of alive... UNTIL the cat dies. The only component in the ENTIRE experiment that hasn't collapsed in its quantum state yet, and been measured doing so, is the unstable atom of some radioactive element whose decay will be detected by the geiger counter. Only the radioactive atom is the only piece whose quantum superposition has not collapsed.

Therefore, the cat does not exist in a superposition. It exists in the definite state of alive... until it is dead.
Our logical reasoning is worth only when we are trying to figure out physicality but for other levels of reality mind is not enough.
Superposition doesn't make any intuitive sense, and so looking at the alternative explanation, many worlds, the obvious winner is 'here's the math, just work with that'.

In other words don't try to use a Quantum thought experiment based on the "macro" world, it doesn't translate.
Superposition works in the "micro, micro miniature" Quantum world.

"Many worlds" is a terrible name -- it gives the impression that tremendous amounts of matter just pop into existence. Watch a few Sean Carroll videos about it; his explanation is pretty compelling. It's so simple, in a way -- the key idea is that WE can be in a state of superposition as well, e.g. about which slit the particle went through. There aren't many universes -- there's just ONE universe, but it's a quantum universe, and all of the possibilities exist within it.

Once you start to get your head around it, you think "Yeah, come to think of it, where do those Copenhagen guys get off insisting that the universe is classical, so the quantum stuff has to 'collapse' when we observe it? If all the particles in it are quantum, what would prevent US from being in a superposition?"

Simple explanation:  Everything has an Uncertainty Principle. For objects asymptotically lighter than the Planck mass this is the Heisenberg UP based upon the properties of a bundle of pilot waves. For objects asymptotically heavier than the Planck mass this is the Fuerth UP based upon classical Brownian motion on the same scale. The cat starts to go into a superposition of states, but classical Brownian motion mixes them up and produces an outcome where only one of the states is observed.

There's really no such thing as a (classical) particle in the quantum realm. The bulk or volume of an electron (or any other fundamental quantum field perturbation) deserves a unique, non-classical term just so that we can stop with all the needless exceptions/qualifiers/disclaimers (i.e., baggage) that comes with using the word particle. And a perfectly fine term/word already exists: wavicle. Wavicles have no equivalent to anything in the classical world...because it is an object that exists in a different...realm. Upon running tests and experiments, we can attribute the following properties of [this] wavicle as follows [itemize here]. End of story. That several of those properties might defy one's classical intuitions is not a bug. It's precisely what is expected if we are in fact dealing with a different realm. And after discovering this realm 100 years ago, how is it that we haven't completely made sense of it? Undoubtedly, it's because physicists are just screwing off.

The interference pattern of electrons through a slot can be simply explained. Atoms follow very strict rules about energy states, electron configurations, spin, etc. the slots would have to be so small to exclude other stray electrons, that the fired electron would be passing incredibly close to the material the slots are in. This would create a reaction in the atoms of the material, that would travel through the electrons of that material at near light speed. This changing attraction/repulsion effect at the slot, that would follow very strict mathematical variances, would act like the electromagnet coils in old CRT screens, deflecting the electron exact amounts left and right. It’s likely not an interference pattern, but just the deflection angle.

One way to describe entanglement is "X + Y = 7". The two variables together are entangled and equal a known value. If you measure X and find it is equal to 2 then instantaneously (faster than light speed) Y becomes equal to 5, even if you moved Y far away from X. Strange. How did Y "know" to become the value of 5? What if X had turned out to be equal to 4? Y would have instantly "changed" to become 3.

In fact, you can see that there is no instant communication between the variables. You defined their relationship with the formula at the beginning, which entangled them. By defining the two together as a single variable, they became one system. Measure a part of it and you know what the other part equals. Not so mysterious after all. It just seems strange to us when we apply this idea to particles or qubits.

The meaning of superposition in the Copenhagen interpretation is not correctly portrayed here in my view. The Copenhagen interpretation denies that there is any direct relation between the wave function and reality. The wave function (which is the thing being in a superposition) is just a mathematical object describing the system. It is related by the measurement and collapse postulate to reality. So in the Copenhagen interpretation, quantum mechanics is a theory predicting the outcomes of measurements and that is it. It is not a description of reality. Quantum mechanics can say nothing about the 'reality' of the cat in the box if no measurement on it is done. The interpretation that because the wave function at some point is in a superposition of cat-dead and cat-alive, means that the cat is dead and alive at the same time is not correct.

I feel like it should be made clear that, we conduct the experiments, we see results like the interference pattern, and then we come up with mathematical models to fit what we see. There have been dozens of models (interpretations) people have come up with to explain quantum behavior, but for most of them, either an experiment eventually proves it wrong, or people decide that parts of the model are more complicated than they need to be and there's no way to ever test them (unfalsifiable). After almost 100 years, we haven't found an experiment that contradicts the Copenhagen interpretation. But that doesn't mean we won't. Newtonian physics was truth until relativity came along and showed that it's just an approximation. So best to assume everything is an approximation.

Not true; the state of the box contents is entangled with the rest of the universe in many many places. Most obviously with the person who packed the box, but also more fundamentally with the energy states of the photons that bounced off it before it entered the box.

That's the flaw with Schroedinger's Cat thought experiment; it's impossible for a macroscopic object such as a Cat to enter a box without becoming entangled with some aspect of the surrounding universe.
Moreover it's impossible for the box itself to create perfect isolation between the exterior & interior of the box; we as observers are already entangled with the state of the Cat.

I think there is a more useful thought experiment than Schrödinger’s cat. Imagine a box in which you have a standard coin, heads on one side, tails on the other. But this coin is continually spinning and moving around in a box slightly larger than the spinning coin, in a random fashion, until you open the box, when it stops and you can observe it’s position and orientation. At any given instant, that coin may be in any position and orientation, which can be expressed as a probability wave function. It’s effectively in a superposition of all positions and orientations…until you open the box to observe it. Having observed its position and orientation, that wave function collapsed into a single, specific position and orientation.

Now, imagine the coins are microscopically small and spinning and moving at speeds far too fast for any “typical” imaging to capture, and no “box” is needed to obscure the position or orientation, it’s high speed and size already obscure that. Now imagine a double slit barrier where the coins can only pass through each slit in a small subset of positions/orientations. If you measure the position and orientation immediately after it passes through a slit. It’s always going to be in a position/orientation allowed by that slit. But, if you measure it at some distance away from the wall, you won’t know which slit it passed through, nor what the position and orientation were when I passed through, only what its position and orientation is at the time you observed it later. It’s still unknown even after passing through the slits, because it was still in random motion, still in its superposition, and it’s probability wave didn’t collapse when it passed through the slit. The probability wave collapsed only when you later measured it, leaving you with only probabilistic information about which slit it passed through.

Schrödinger’s cat is useful for showing that some interpretations of QM aren’t valid. The above is useful for explaining why the double slit experiment gives the results it gives, and may offer insights about how quantum reality operates.

You missed out that the way that we "detect" which slit the photon passes through is to polarize the light and use a perpendicularly polarized filter over one of the slits. So you know that the photon would be stopped by the polarization filter and thus if it goes through, it was through the slit without the filter. The problem with this is that perpendicularly polarized waves cannot constructively or destructively interfere, so by adding the polarization filter you've removed the opportunity for the interference pattern, so if you did see an interference pattern, THAT would be the surprising thing.

The double split experiment does not prove the Copenhagen interpretation over pilot wave theory.

Superposition isn't really all that crazy. In waves, it happens all the time. Like, if you hit a drum, what you hear is a superposition of many many frequencies, giving you the overall pitch and timbre of a given drum. - Mathematically speaking, it's literally just an addition. You directly add "pure" (sinusoidal) waves on top of each other and get an arbitrary wave shape.

In quantum mechanics, it turns out information (such as whether cat is alive or dead) is encoded in a wave, the amplitude of which gives the probability of what state is correct. And in a sense, evidence towards one outcome or the other is just multiple such belief states in superposition, each slightly cancelling out one possibility while boosting the other. If you do this enough, you can arrive at a near perfect belief about the cat. Say, it is alive. (Yay!)
Such evidence might be that the box bumps around a bit, that you can hear the cat through the box, that the cat's body heat seeps out of the box... - Very very subtle information can be enough to significantly bias your belief about the cat's current state. So it needs to be incredibly well-isolated from the world to make this work. Essentially no information can seep out of the box or else the whole thing is spoiled.

Note, I talked about beliefs which can be personal. It's not quite arbitrary beliefs: It should be rational ones, based on the information you get. I.e. if you have some current believe, and are presented with new evidence, you will update your belief according to the strength of the evidence. But it is personal.
To see this, just imagine nested boxes. The innermost box contains Schrödinger's cat. The next box contains Schrödinger pondering the fate of his cat, and outside of that, you have Wigner, a friend of Schrödinger.
If Schrödinger's box is isolated enough from the outside world, Wigner can't know whether the cat is alive or dead, even if Schrödinger already opened the cat's box. Schrödinger, at that point, already knows the cat's fate (it's dead :( ) but for the rest of the world, and Wigner in particular, to know, his box needs to be unsealed first.

In order to exploit any of these Quantum phenomena, you need to know when to expect them.
One interpretation that makes this way of thinking particularly explicit used to be called Quantum Bayesianism, but got shortened to the very cute QBism. I like that particular interpretation quite a bit. - It basically starts with the classical Bayes' Rule and modifies it a bit to make it amendable to Quantum Mechanics instead.
The other one I'm fond of is Relational Quantum Mechanics (RQM) which also makes this quantum information relative to a given observer.
They are all in a camp of QM interpretations that essentially say, in the tradeoff between reality* and locality**, it's reality that needs to go

* reality here means "objective", observer-independent reality. "Real" stuff is whatever doesn't change no matter how you look at it. In particular, a measurement of it can't affect it.
For Schrödinger's Cat that'd mean its fate is predetermined all along whether it is observed or not.
Copenhagen kinda implements this in a limited way, effectively saying a single observation of any observer is enough to "lock in reality": What one observer discovers is gonna hold true for all observers. But the observation itself may break reality for an instant, causing a new reality in which a superposition gets destroyed in favor of a clear fixed state.
QBism and RQM go further and allow instances where different observers may not even agree on the same outcomes.
It's not quite the same thing, but intuitively you could perhaps see this hold if you consider General Relativity and how it is clearly dependent on an observer's frame of reference what outcomes might end up being observed.

** locality roughly means Einstein is right and information can't be sent faster than the speed of light.
nonlocality would mean that, in cases of entangled pairs of particles, if you measure one particle, the information of the result of that measurement travels possibly all the way across the universe in an instant (i.e. faster than light. infinitely fast, even) to make the other particle have the correct state according to the way the two particles got entangled.
That may be appealing to some, but imo it overcomplicates the issue at hand. I.e. entanglement is really a single piece of information that is independent of a later measurement: A decision is made, how the particle pairs are created. If you happen to know of the decision, you already know "If you measure state x, the other particle will be in state y", well before the particle arrives in your detector. It's only paradoxical if you think of it from the uninformed perspective: "I see that every time detector 1 measures x, detector 2 measures y. How do the particles coordinate???" but that's just a matter of you personally not knowing a thing about the history of these particles.
At any rate, if you rather let go of this in favor of an absolute, observer-independent reality, you'll prefer things like Pilot Wave Theory.

I think the oft-contemplated Everett Many Worlds Theory solves this issue by having a distribution of realities, all of which come to pass, but only one of which a particular version of you has access to, so I think technically speaking it's also in team reality breaks. But I'm not actually quite sure.

One final thing on Cophenhagen: I believe this one has effectively been ruled out now, with the discovery of a new set of Bell-like inequalities that directly pit against each other the following four properties: (as per the paper "A strong no-go theorem on the Wigner’s friend paradox")

- Quantum Mechanics is consistent (its rules always apply)
- Experimenters can freely choose their experiments (free will exists)
- physics are local (as discussed, no faster than light information flow)
- outcomes of measurements are absolute, objective facts for all observers (If I think find the cat is alive, you must agree with me once you observe it)

That last thing is an assumption Copenhagen makes. And at least one of the above must be wrong. And rejecting any one of them destroys Copenhagen. So it can not be correct.
As discussed, RQM and QBism are not affected by this, and neither would be Pilot Wave Theory (I think) or Many Worlds.

Even in a hypothetical scenario, there is one logical flaw in the cat experiment. The cat would really be in a superposition state after you close the box only if the box is isolated and cannot interact with the environment in any way. However, this cannot happen as the box is exchanging photons with its environment constantly and thus exchanging them with the observer indirectly (or directly, depending on the observer's position). Hence, the superposition has already collapsed even before you open the box, i.e., it is indeed in one of those two states and the reality has already been fixed for your Universe. One clarification: each electron still only hits one spot on the plate. It’s wave function results in the probability of where “it” will hit. There’s a very good chance it will hit the middle amplified wave, a decreasing chance it will hit the other, smaller amplitude waves, and a very small chance it will hit the troughs. A single electron will not make that pattern, but will hit somewhere on the plate According to the probability function. If you send a bunch of single electrons through one at a time you will get the wave pattern on the screen. The illustration sort of implies you need a bunch of electrons to make it work.

What a disappointment of a video: Shrodinger wasn’t saying supposition was ridiculous, quite the opposite.

He was explaining how it can’t be scaled up, just the molecules of air bumping on the Geiger counter’s probe (without even considering the molecules part of the Geiger counter itself) would collapse the wave function to the cat being either dead or alive and no longer in superposition.

The more stuff you put in your system the more rapidly the wave function collapses and starts behaving the way we perceive the word.

The thing is, in none of the interpretations is the cat actually in a superposition. Dianna mentioned, that the act of measuring causes the wave function to collapse. It's why the electrons form a discrete pattern when measured directly at one of the slits. But what is measurement? In this context a measurement is any coupling of your quantum system (the decay product in Schrödingers experiment) with a macroscopic system. That macroscopic system is the Geiger-Muller counter. So even in the thought experiment, the quantum system is measured, the wave function collapses and the get is either dead or alive, never a superposition of both. The question which interpretation is correct, however, still remains.

Fun fact: There was even a debate at one time if this "magical concept" on measurement requires consciousness, i.e. if and observing mind might make a measurement. It doesn't, it's just coupling to a large enough system so that quantum effects have a very discrete, deterministic (one might say sharp) average with almost no deviation.

from schrodingers point of view before opening the box the cat is both dead and alive. But not from the point of view of the cat. From the cats point of view he must be in a definite state. And this state must be real. So either the cats state is already defined before schrodinger opens the box (in which case it would be very hard to explain interference) or there are 2 real worlds, one in which the cat is dead and one in which it is alive

the same thing happens when the scientist opens the box. Now his state becomes entangled with the cats, and he experiences it as alive or dead. But from the point of view of someone outside the lab this information has not been revealed yet, so the cats state is still a superposition of dead and alive, the only difference is that now it is entangled with the scientists state
So, if a tree falls in the forest and no one is there to hear it, it remains in a state of superposition in which it both does and doesn't make a sound

Because causality has a speed limit every point in space sees itself as the closest to the present moment. When we look out into the universe, we see the past which is made of particles. When we try to look at smaller and smaller sizes and distances, we are actually looking closer and closer to the present moment. The wave property of particles appears when we start looking into the future of that particle. It is a probability wave because the future is probabilistic. Wave function collapse happens when we bring a particle into the present/past. GR is predictable because it takes place in the predictable past and the probabilistic wave properties of particles takes place in the probabilistic future.

Although I always cringe from the sensational news with anything related to quantum mechanics - like teleportation (most likely quantum one, but who needs that in the news title, just teleportation brings more clicks) and superposition/entanglement, I like the conclusion of the video - at least it is genuine.
Personally - yeah, some math is there and it accurately describes some number of phenomenon, results of which can be observed.
Regarding what really happens there - I'm more on the "non-believer" camp - e.g. this explanation that "electron is "more" (acts like) wave and it goes through both slits and then it interferes with itself" - unfortunately does not resonate with me at all (no pun intended).
What I would say as a nuclear physicist is rather sides of the slits - and the closeness to it - affects the things which pass by.
E.g. the electron which flies in the dead center of the slit - will have been affected by balanced electromagnetic forces from the atoms in the slit sides, so it will go straight.
On the contrary, the electron which goes at some multiple of its wavelength (which happens to accurately describe the more general term from fluid dynamics "characteristic size") - will be affected "that much", so it will be diverted to some side, on a certain degree.
So the interference picture you see could be basically the statistical summary of where the initial electron went in the slit (what was the initial direction at source), multiplied by slit interaction.
You can see such phenomenon with you eyes if you stare at the sun at sunset (kind of gravitational interaction, as well as atmosphere, I'd say), or if you stare at some point light from the corner of the wall - you'll never get the "exact" shadow (not even counting bounced light) - you'll get a soft shadow which hints some interaction of the light with the atoms in the corner of the wall.
Obviously I didn't work researching this particular phenomenon (passing light through the slits), maybe if I worked on it - I would have changed my mind.
From my background - so far, unfortunately I can't accept the other effects of quantum mechanics like entanglement - my domain is causality, and the real world use case U(235,92) + n → Xe(139,54) + Sr(95,38) + 2n - given the result of the reaction - Sr-95 I ALWAYS know that the other half is Xe-139 - just because the numbers add up to that, and not because "the excited U-235 atom was some form of entanglement" (I hope you understand what I'm trying to make analogy for here)

The thing with the cat in the box is, that opening the box and looking inside is not the moment it is "measured" or "observed". The state of the system is already determined when the decay happened and interacted with something else.  The moment the wavefunction interacts with something it breaks down and is determined. So the cat is either dead or alive but not both.

5:45 This relates to the Heisenberg uncertainty principle. By putting the detector there you get more precision on the electron's position, which means you have less precision on its momentum. Physically, what's happening is your detector is using photons to detect the electron and those photons are affecting its momentum, thus changing the experiment.
